    Cytotoxic Effect of Silver Nanoparticles Synthesized by Green Methods in Cancer

    • Mariana Morais
      Mariana Morais
      Molecular Oncology and Viral Pathology Group, IPO-Porto Research Center (CI-IPOP), Portuguese Oncology Institute of Porto (IPO-Porto), Rua António Bernardino de Almeida, 4200-072 Porto, Portugal

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Cancer is a major public health problem, but despite the several treatment approaches available, patients develop resistance in short time periods, making overcoming resistance or finding more efficient treatments an imperative challenge. Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have been described as an alternative option due to their physicochemical properties. The scope of this review was to systematize the available scientific information concerning these characteristics in AgNPs synthesized according to green chemistry’s recommendations as well as their cytotoxicity in different cancer models. This is the first paper analyzing, correlating, and summarizing AgNPs’ main parameters that modulate their cellular effect, including size, shape, capping, and surface plasmon resonance profile, dose range, and exposure time. It highlights the strong dependence of AgNPs’ cytotoxic effects on their characteristics and tumor model, making evident the strong need of standardization and full characterization. AgNPs’ application in oncology research is a new, open, and promising field and needs additional studies.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cancer is a major public health problem and it is expected to be the greatest obstacle to the increase of life expectancy worldwide in the current century. In 2018, there were an estimated 18.1 million new cancer cases and 9.6 million cancer deaths worldwide, and this incidence is estimated to double by 2035.(1) Actually, the fast development of medical imaging techniques enabled an earlier cancer diagnosis of previously undetectable tumors.(2) Moreover, several new treatments are already available, but most of them are quite expensive, and eventually, patients develop resistance to them. Consequently, the global cost of oncology treatments’ is expected to annually grow from 7% to 10% throughout 2020, when it will surpass $150 billion.(3)
    There are several antineoplastic therapeutic approaches available such as surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone, target, and immune therapies. However, all of them are associated with resistance development and the mechanisms behind it are being studied.(4)
    The mechanisms behind chemotherapy resistance are complex, being dependent on many factors such as the deregulation of pathways related to cell death inhibition, deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) damage repair, angiogenesis, drug metabolism, and uptake or efflux of drugs, as well as changes in drug targets.(5) On the other hand, radiotherapy loses its efficiency in tumors that present a hypoxic microenvironment, since hypoxic cancer cells are not sensitive to ionizing radiation because they do not generate the reactive oxygen species (ROS) responsible for triggering the death pathways.(6,7)
    Hormone therapy is one of the approaches to some tumors’ treatment, typically the hormone dependent tumors, such as prostate or breast cancers. However, these tumors frequently develop resistance to this therapy by altering specific signaling pathways that are responsible for their dependence on hormones. The activation of alternative signaling pathways will facilitate the tumor growth and progression.(8)
    In the past two decades, target therapies have been earning recognition because of their key role in cancer patients’ treatment. This approach is more precise and direct to key molecules that are deregulated. Unfortunately, these therapies result in high rates of resistance development due to genetic and epigenetic alterations in their targets, activation of alternative pathways, and phenotype alterations.(9)
    Nowadays, the modulation of the immune system (immune therapy) as a therapeutic approach regained a lot of attention, due to the major impact in patients’ overall survival when compared with others. However, its beneficial effects are restricted to a limited number of cancer patients.(10) In fact, the loss of T cell function, the downregulation of tumor antigen presentation that leads to lack of T cell recognition, and the development of escape mutation variants in the tumor are some of the resistance mechanisms proposed.(11)
    Over the past two decades, due to the increasing research in the nanotechnology area, the number of scientific works in the scope of nanotherapies, namely, regarding nanoparticles, has been growing. Thus, research involving their use associated with other therapies has significantly gained attention in several diseases, including cancer. Nanoparticles are defined as small organized structures ranging in size from 1 to 100 nm.(12) Specifically, silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) present specific chemical and physical properties, due to their confined size and high surface area-to-volume ratio, that grant their application in several technological and biomedical fields, including cancer treatment.(13)
    AgNPs can be synthesized through several methods, e.g., physical, chemical, and biological. Nowadays, a green synthesis approach is always preferable, regardless of the main nature of the raw materials. The green synthesis of AgNPs occurs every time that green raw materials and/or sustainable synthesis techniques are used. Whenever possible, the syntheses should rely on low-hazard chemical reactions through the use of safe and low-toxic reagents, use of safe solvents, and separation products, like water and plant extracts, minimization of energy consumption, and the use of products safe for human and the global environment. Nanoparticles can be synthesized by green synthesis methods based on physical or chemical methods (like, for example, microwave-based or ultrasound-based synthesis, photocatalysis, hydro- or solvothermal synthesis, etc.) and biological methods (phyto, bacterial, fungi, or algae based synthesis).(14) The different methods for the synthesis of AgNPs originate from nanomaterials of different sizes and shapes, among other distinct physicochemical properties. A thorough discussion of synthesis methods and AgNPs properties (like size and shape) can be found in the scientific literature.(12)
    The biological synthesis approach of AgNPs is coherent with the idea of sustainable chemistry, being particularly interesting because it uses environmentally benign and renewable materials derived from bacteria, fungi, plant extracts, yeasts, viruses, and algae, being divided in microbial synthesis and phyto-based synthesis.(13) Moreover, it avoids the use of hazardous and toxic reagents and the use of high temperatures or pressure during the synthesis, also resulting in higher biocompatibility, lower overall chemical contamination, and higher energy-savings.(15) Nevertheless, the microorganism-based syntheses methods are characterized by low yields, due to their dependence on organism type, cellular growth, enzyme activity, and the different biocatalysts.(16) Additionally, the complete mechanism of microbial synthesis has not yet been fully clarified, even though some progress has been made by using specific microbial proteins or peptides in the synthesis. These specific reagents will allow in the future the rational design of new molecules that further boost the synthesis mechanisms, purity, and yields of final products. On the other hand, the phytochemical methods allow high rates of synthesis and monodispersity and stability of the AgNPs. These syntheses are based on the reduction character of some polysaccharides, enzymes, proteins, or amino acids constituents of plant extracts. When specific plants or plants’ parts are used, the size and morphology of the obtained AgNPs are more predictable, and hence, one can say it is easier to control the final product. Nevertheless, to obtain specific modifications in AgNPs controlled by the operator remains a challenge using plants and parts of plants. The reduction character and capping capacity of some polysaccharides, enzymes, proteins, or amino acids constituents of plant extracts influence the physicochemical properties of AgNPs, and hence, the knowledge of the exact chemical composition of the natural products is of outmost importance. In this scope, pharmacognosy is a promising scientific area to better assist that challenge, since it devotes its expertise in the acquisition of knowledge of raw materials of biological nature through the study of the composition and concentration of natural substances, fundamentally of plant and animal origin, and the therapeutic or toxic effect of their active principles. Furthermore, there is the possibility of using medicinal plants that, besides possessing reducing chemical constituents, also have several therapeutic capabilities. These can act as reinforcements for the therapy or the opposite, interfering in the desired therapy. Nevertheless, overall, the phytosynthesis takes the lead among the green synthesis methods because of the triple function possibilities of the compounds involved, namely, its reducing, capping, and therapeutic effects. Considering the vast existence of diverse natural products, as sustainable and environmentally materials susceptible to use for nanoparticles synthesis, the scientific literature includes numerous works involving the green synthesis of nanoparticles. Some works are aimed at the physicochemical studies of the synthesis process, and others are aimed at the study of the nanomaterial’s application in biological, environmental, or toxicological demands. Each work involves a different source material for the NPs synthesis and different physicochemical properties of the obtained products, with a consequent result in the target application. Generally, the choice of source materials for NPS synthesis relies on the possible available knowledge of the constituents of the source products, considering the reduction potential and stabilizing capacity that some substances might have. More information about this subject can be found in other review works in the scientific literature.(16)
    The main disadvantages of green nanoparticle synthesis from phyto and bacterial cultures are low synthesis yield and the complicated procedures for the isolation of the NPs without damaging or disrupting their physicochemical integrity. Additionally, it is very difficult to control the pH, temperature, amounts of specific constituents from the natural sources that all together influence the nanoparticle synthesis and final products (size, shape, chemical and optical properties). This information is discussed in other reviews dedicated to the subject.(16,17)
    The scope of this review was to gather and systematize the information available in the scientific literature regarding the characteristics of AgNPs synthesized through green methods and their cytotoxicity effect in different cancer models.

    2. Evidence Acquisition

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A literature search in PubMed was conducted using the search terms “green synthesis”, “silver nanoparticles”, and “cancer”. All papers until the date of April 14, 2019, were included. By combination of the three keywords (inclusion criteria), 168 papers were selected to review. After abstract analysis, 12 papers were excluded because either they were review papers (11) or we did not have access to the full text (1). After full text analysis, another 42 papers were also excluded because they did not use AgNPs, they did not use nanoparticles synthesized by green methods, or their effects in tumor models were not included in the works. The 114 remaining full papers were analyzed according to both the main characteristics of the AgNPs and their cytotoxicity (Figure 1). To improve the current knowledge of the mechanism of action of AgNPs in the different tumor cells, information regarding other phenotypic assays was also collected when described by the authors. All this information was organized and analyzed as explained in the following chapter.

    3. Evidence Synthesis

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In order to review and resume the main information available, all the data collected from the selected papers were organized according to the tumor organ or system. The least incident tumors were grouped in one table named Others, which includes glioblastoma, neuroblastoma, retinoblastoma, myeloblastic leukemia, and fibrosarcoma. In this group the limited number of studies available for each cancer model does not support an individual statistical analysis performed in the other models.
    Thus, a total of eight tables, corresponding to the eight cancer models, were created as presented in Table 1 and also shown in Tables 2–9.
    Table 1. Cancer Model Groups Reviewed in the Present Paper
    cancer models table
    Breast Table 2
    Lung Table 3
    Head and neckpharynxTable 4
    oral
    epithelioma
    GynecologicovaryTable 5
    cervical
    Urologicrenal cell carcinomaTable 6
    prostate
    DigestiveliverTable 7

    gastric
    pancreatic
    SkinmelanomaTable 8
    epidermoid
    OthersglioblastomaTable 9
    neuroblastoma
    retinoblastoma
    myeloblastic leukemia
    fibrosarcoma

    a

    Abbreviations: SPR, surface plasmon resonance; IC50, half inhibitory concentration; LD50, half lethal dose.

    b

    In these studies the size of nanoparticles was obtained by DLS or XRD.

    Curcuma longa L. extract (tumeric)447Spherical6.132–100 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA54911.11 μg/mLNHDFIC50 > 100 μg/mLAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity but less toxicity compared with cisplatin(25)

    P. multiflorus extract460Spherical20.87b1–100 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA549   AgNPs induce apoptosis through ROS formation and increase of p53 and caspase-3 expression and inhibits cell migration(37)
    Indigofera tinctoria leaf extract427Spherical9–266.25–100 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA54956.62 μg/mL  AgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity(107)
    Beta vulgaris extract450Spherical5–2010–100 μg/mL72HLung AdenocarcinomaA54948.2 μg/mLVero and Hbl100Lower toxicityAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity through apoptosis (nuclear changes such as chromatin condensation and nuclear fragmentation)(33)
    Ficus religiosa leaves extract421Spherical210.05–5 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA5491.9 μg/mL  AgNPs induce generation of ROS, depletion of MMP and antioxidant activity of cell, fragmentation of DNA, increased expressions of cleaved PARP and Caspase; activation of caspase 8, caspase 3, lamins increasing apoptosis; in vivo there is alteration of most markers studied but they all returned to normal after washout period(21)
    cell free culture supernatant of E. coli VM1422Well-defined cubic phase10–150–125 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA54940 μg/mLVeroIC50 = 115 μg/mLAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity(108)
    Azadirachta indica leaves extract420Spherical20–600–240 ppm24HLung Adenosquamous CarcinomaNCI-H460 HDFaNo toxicityAgNPs increased ROS activity leading to apoptosis with condensed and fragmented chromatin in cancer cells; no effects in erythrocytes(51)

    D. morbifera leaf extract458Polygonal20–501–100 μg/mL48HLung AdenocarcinomaA549 HaCaTLower toxicityAgNPs induced apoptosis and increased the anticancer effect of ginsenoside compound K(110)
    Styrax benzoin extract450Spherical12–381–5 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA549 HaCat, Raw264.7No toxicityAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity(87)
    D. morbifera Léveille leaves extract   1–50 μg/mL48HLung AdenocarcinomaA549   AgNPs induce ROS generation by p38 phosphorylation; induce apoptosis; downregulate EGFR and decrease cell migration(38)
    Longan peel powder Spherical8–222–30 μg/mL72HMetastatic Non-Small-Cell Lung CancerH12995.33 μg/mL  AgNPs induce apoptosis, decrease the NF-kB and bcl2 transcriptional activity as well as increase caspase3 and survivin. There is a tumor-size decrease.(55)
    Taxus yunnanensis Callus extract449Spherical6.4–27.210–125 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA549   No effect of AgNPs in lung adenocarcinoma cells(90)
    Butea monosperma leaf extract440–475Spherical20–800.3–2.5 μg/mL24 and 48HLung AdenocarcinomaA549 HUVEC and ECV-304No toxicityAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity(49)

    Rosa damascena petals aqueous extract420Spherical15–2720–120 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA54980 μg/mLHemolytic activity assayNo hemolytic activity against erythrocytesAgNPs induced dose dependent cytotoxicity(54)

    Phytolacca decandra300–350Spherical91b20–140 μg/mL Lung AdenocarcinomaA54980 μg/mL  AgNPs induced cell membrane disruption, DNA fragmentation, and upregulation of caspase 3 inducing apoptosis(111)
    Coptis chinensis aqueous extract428Spherical6–455–20 μg/mL72HLung AdenocarcinomaA549   AgNPs induced DNA breakage and apoptosis, inhibited migration and cell invasion, and upregulated caspase3 and Bax while downregulating Bcl(39)
    PSP001 extracted from fruit rind of Punica granatum440Spherical300.01–200 μg/mL24HLung AdenocarcinomaA549 3T3-L1 and hemolysis assayLow hemolysisAgNPs induced apoptosis and inhibition of wound closure(112)

    Abbreviations: SPR, surface plasmon resonance; IC50, half inhibitory concentration; LD50 half lethal dose.

    b

    In these studies the size of nanoparticles was obtained by DLS or XRD.

    Regarding the main characteristics of AgNPs, some parameters like the natural source of the capping (reducing and/or stabilizing agent), the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) peak, shape, size, size determination method, and concentration range of AgNPs tested were collected from the papers. Additionally, concerning AgNPs’ cytotoxicity, tumor model, cancer cell line, time of exposure, IC50 (half maximal inhibitory concentration)/LD50 (median lethal dose), normal cell line, and toxicity in normal cell lines were collected and also compiled in tables.

    4. Mechanisms of AgNPs’ Toxicity

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The studies reviewed here comprise the evaluation of several cellular parameters related to the AgNPs’ cellular uptake, DNA damage, mitochondrial damage, cell membrane damage, and apoptosis. Moreover, pathways deregulation and effects on migration and invasion capacity were also assessed. The studies also assessed the nuclear damage through mutagenesis analysis, DNA fragmentation, and strand scission detection. Concerning mitochondrial damage, the amount of ROS and oxidative stress were evaluated as well as the mitochondrial membrane potential. Apoptosis was evaluated not only in terms of the stage of apoptosis but also in regard to the main pathways involved. This review confirmed that among the described toxicity mechanisms, the increase in ROS production and apoptosis induction are the most common.
    Most AgNPs enter the cells by endocytosis (either clathrin-dependent or clathrin-independent) although some may enter through diffusion, lipid peroxidation, and even disruption of membrane.(18,19) By endocytosis, AgNPs are taken up by endosomes that develop into lysosomes which have lower pH that will favor the release of Ag+.(20) However, the exact mechanism of cellular uptake still needs to be clarified.
    According to most of the studies, AgNPs exert their toxicity inside the cell in three main locations which are summarized in Figure 2: cytoplasmatic membrane, mitochondria, and nucleus. The damage induced in these locations will ultimately lead to apoptosis (even though sometimes necrosis is also reported).
    Several authors report the presence of membrane blebbing as an example of damage in the cytoplasmatic membrane.(23,24) This damage is also supported by studies showing an increase of the leakage of the cytosolic enzyme lactate dehydrogenase from cells treated with AgNPs, which is a common indicator of cytoplasmatic membrane disruption.(25−27)
    AgNPs’ toxicity inside the mitochondria is mainly due to the increase in ROS production. These species are mostly produced in this organelle, during oxidative phosphorylation when some electrons end up escaping and bind to O2 forming the radical ·O2– that can be converted into other radicals. The increase in ROS production is described to be due to nanoparticle surface chemistry, depletion of antioxidant molecules (such as glutathione) via binding Ag+ to thiol groups, altered enzymatic production of ROS, inhibition of electron transport chain, and decrease of superoxide dismutase and catalase’s expression (enzymes that neutralize ROS).(19) Mitochondria’s function is also impaired by the depolarization of mitochondrial membrane.(28−30) This polarization is required for functions like canonical protein import mechanisms, ATP production, and proper responses to cellular calcium concentration flux. The direct inhibition of electron transport chain enzymes in complex I, II, III, and/or IV (depending on the tissue) is another reported damage caused by AgNPs in mitochondria.(31)
    Inside the nucleus, AgNPs can induce much damage in the DNA, depending on the nanoparticle chemical and physical characteristics and on the cell line, and this damage highly affects the cell viability. AgNPs may induce mutations, fragmentation of DNA, formation of DNA ladders with low molecular weight, oxidation of DNA bases, single or double strand breaks, as well as formation of cross-links or DNA adducts, chromatin condensation, and fragmentation.(19,23,28,32,33) This damage may be caused by direct binding of AgNPs to DNA or to its associated proteins, mitotic spindle components or event through the oxidative stress caused by the AgNPs.(34)
    Moreover, AgNPs have been shown to alter the regulation of several genes, among which were metallothionein, heat shock protein, and histone families as well as genes involved in DNA repair, such as RAD51C and growth arrest and DNA-damage-inducible 45 (GADD45).(18)
    One of the genes whose expression is downregulated by AgNPs is vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), a proangiogenic factor.(35) Angiogenesis is the process of formation of new blood vessels growing from the capillary endothelium of already existing vessels and seems to be inhibited by AgNPs through the downregulation of VEGF.(19) Additionally, AgNPs seem to successfully inhibit cell migration and invasion, which shows their potential as antimetastatic drug.(29,36−39)
    Ultimately, as previously mentioned, the damage caused by AgNPs leads to cell death. Most of the studies show that all this damage leads to cell cycle arrest and consequently apoptosis. Apoptosis is generally inducted by two major signaling pathways: the intrinsic pathway (regulated by caspase 9) and the extrinsic pathway (regulated by caspase 8).(21) AgNPs seem to be able to induce apoptosis through either of these pathways, depending on its physical and chemical properties.(21,22) Jang and co-workers have successfully synthesized AgNPs that were able to up-regulate the p53 tumor suppressor gene and subsequently increase the expressions of proapoptotic Bax, caspase-3, and caspase-9, inducing apoptosis through the intrinsic pathway.(40) On the other hand, the AgNPs synthesized by Nakkala and co-workers were able to upregulate both caspase 8 and caspase 9, inducing apoptosis by the intrinsic and extrinsic pathway.(21) However, the responsible components for this ability in both studies were not identified.
    Nevertheless, it is important to highlight that in most cases when the effect of AgNPs in cancer and normal cells is compared, normal cells display lower toxicity or no toxicity at all. This lower toxicity in normal cells may be due to the use of natural compounds as surface capping for AgNPs or as a consequence of specific physical characteristics of the nanoparticles. Additionally, it may be due to the highest uptake of AgNPs by cancer cells when compared with healthy cells, a consequence of their abnormal metabolism and higher proliferation rate which makes them more vulnerable to AgNPs entrance.(41) Moreover, studies that compare the toxicity of AgNPs using tumor cells and normal cells show higher IC50 values for normal cell lines, highlighting the biocompatibility potential of most of these AgNPs. In fact, only in the work conducted by Ribeiro and collaborators was the IC50 value of the synthesized AgNPs for normal cell lines higher (5.0 μM) than the IC50 for the colorectal cell line (6.5 μM).(42)

    5. Antineoplastic Effect of AgNPs’ Characteristics in Different Tumor Models

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To better comprehend the effect of SPR and size of AgNPs, as well as the time of exposure during the IC50/LD50 determination, for each cancer model, when the information was available, the graphical representation of SPR (nm) vs size (nm), SPR (nm) vs IC50/LD50 (μg/mL), size (nm) vs IC50/LD50 (μg/mL), and IC50/LD50 (μg/mL) vs exposure time (hours) was conducted. For these analyses, only AgNPs with spherical shapes were considered to avoid possible deviations of observations due to the influence of nanoparticles shape on the activity or other property.

    5.1. Breast Cancer

    The graphical representation of correlations in relation to breast cancer is shown in Figure 3. For the graphical representation of size (nm) vs SPR (nm) in Figure 3A, only studies were considered where AgNPs dimensions were obtained by TEM, HRTEM, SAED, and XRD, aiming at the best compatibility between sizes’ measurements. There seems to be no association between SPR peak and the size of AgNPs. However, one can verify that most of the AgNPs have a SPR peak between 420 and 450 nm, despite the diversity of biological capping, and overall core sizes below 20 nm.
    In Figure 3B, there is no visible correlation between SPR peak and IC50/LD50 values. Yet, it was evident that most of the crossed data points are situated below 20 μg/mL and scattered between 420 and 450 nm SPR wavelengths.
    In Figure 3C, representing size (nm) vs IC50/LD50 (μg/mL), only studies where size analysis was obtained by TEM were considered. There is a higher prevalence of IC50/LD50 values below 20 μg/mL for a range of silver AgNPs between 6.00 and 27.00 nm but no evident association between IC50/LD50 and size. This may be due to the influence of the capping in the cytotoxic effect of AgNPs. In fact, when Coriandrum sativum leaf extract was used by Sathishkumar and co-workers and when Prosopis cineraria leaf extract was used by Jinu and co-workers, biocapped AgNPs of similar sizes (37 and 32 nm, respectively) but different IC50 values at 24 h were obtained (30.50 and 65.27 μg/mL, respectively).(43,44) Additionally, when using Piriformospora indica extract, Aziz and co-workers obtained AgNPs of 10.50 nm, capable of reducing in 50% the cellular viability at a concentration of 1.07 μg/mL at 48 h.(45) Also at 48 h, but by using Beta vulgaris extract in the work of Venugopal and co-workers, the AgNPs of size 12.50 nm allowed obtaining of an IC50 of 47.60 μg/mL.(33) Thus, AgNPs of similar size and different stabilizing chemical agents originated very distinct IC50 values at the same contact time and in the same cancer cell line (MCF-7), stressing the influence of the natural product as capping source in the cytotoxic power of AgNPs.
    Nevertheless, the lack of purification procedures of the AgNPs in some studies may also explain the lack of association between IC50/LD50 and size. In these cases, the concentrations of suspensions used for the IC50/LD50 assays may involve masses other than only the AgNPs, such as compound remains of the synthesis. In fact, in biological synthesis, the use of extracts involves a mixture of compounds not directly related to the synthesis but that are transferred to the final suspensions. When the work of Chahardoli and collaborators and the work of Aziz et al. are compared, differences in the purification procedures resulted in different cytotoxic effects of the AgNPs (IC50/LD50). Chahardoli and co-workers, who synthesized AgNPs using Nigella arvensis L. seed powder extract (size of 8.50 nm), purified the suspension after synthesis through centrifugation (at 8000 rpm for 15 min) and filtration. The obtained IC50/LD50 at 48 h was 100 μg/mL.(46) Instead, Aziz and co-workers who used AgNPs synthesized from Piriformospora indica extract (10.50 nm) treated them by centrifuging the synthesis suspension at 15 000 rpm for 20 min, followed by repeated centrifugation, redispersion and sonication, and finally lyophilization. The obtained IC50 at 48 h was 1.07 μg/mL.(45) Moreover, in another work of Arumai and collaborators, the authors employed repeated centrifugations and washings, with deionized water followed by ethanol, and dried the AgNPs in a hot air oven for 2 h at 60 °C. Afterward the obtained AgNPs were crushed into powder.(25) The authors observed that the Camellia sinensis L. extract (green tea) based AgNPs presented an average size of 8.37 nm and IC50 of 20.97 μg/mL at 24 h contact time. In the work of Heydari and co-workers, the authors determined a IC50 value of 0.04 μg/mL (at 24h exposure time) using AgNPs of 40.00 nm size and capped with oak fruit hull extract.(47) Nevertheless, this IC50 value was reported when using the AgNPs in the suspension obtained after synthesis, without any purification treatment. When the AgNPs were purified by centrifugation and washing (10 000 rpm, 10 min), the IC50 value reported was 50.00 μg/mL. These previous observations and analysis reported in this review indicate the enormous importance for proper AgNPs purification steps after their syntheses based on natural products, prior to any cytotoxic assays.
    In other published papers the authors do not mention any post-treatment of the syntheses product or do not describe the conditions of centrifugation in the purification methods: velocity (RCF, relative centrifugal force; RPM, revolutions per minute), time, and temperature. In conclusion, besides the capping source used for stabilization of the AgNPs, the purification techniques applied after the biological synthesis seem to also influence the IC50 values referenced in the papers.
    Figure 3D reveals a high dispersion of IC50/LD50 values throughout contact times of 24, 48, and 72 h with the cancer cell line MCF-7. This is easily perceived when comparing AgNPs with Ganoderma neo-kaponicum micelia hot aqueous extracts capping synthesized by Kaler and co-workers, AgNPs with A. asphodeloides extract capping synthesized by Lee and co-workers, and AgNPs with P. tuberosa aqueous extract capping synthesized by Satpathy and co-workers.(24,36,48) In the Kaler work, a IC50 value of 6 μg/mL was obtained after an exposure time of 24 h. In the work of Lee, after an exposure time of 48 h, IC50 values were 2.5 μg/mL, and in the latter work of Kaler, after an exposure time of 72 h, IC50 values were 3.859 μg/mL. This may indicate that in the case of this cell line (MCF-7), the capping constitution may have more influence than the time of exposure.

    5.2. Lung Cancer

    Figure 4 includes several graphical representations between AgNPs parameters and cellular cytotoxicity results in assays with lung cancer cellular models. In Figure 4A, there was no evident correlation between the SPR (nm) and the size (nm) of the AgNPs synthesized for the lung cancer cytotoxicity assays. In fact, different SPRs, namely, 410, 420, and 450 nm were associated with AgNPs with similar sizes of 40–50 nm.(49−51) On the other hand, small sized AgNPs were associated with higher SPR values (near 450 nm). As an exception, in the study of Patra and co-workers, the SPR value of 450 nm was associated with AgNPs with 50 nm of size. According to Kummara and co-workers, the AgNPs, with 40 nm of size and a SPR of 420 nm were able to reduce the cell viability of NCI-H460 cells (non-small-cell lung cancer cells) in a dose dependent manner, even though the IC50/LD50 values are not indicated.(51) In a study performed by Arumai Selvan and co-workers, the AgNPs with Curcuma longa L. (tumeric) capping, with Allium sativum L. extract, and with Camellia sinensis L. extract capping showed sizes of 6.13, 8.19, and 8.37 nm and SPR of 447, 449, and 451 nm, respectively.(25) The in vitro studies revealed that the smallest AgNPs presented the lowest values of IC50/LD50 observed (11.11 μg/mL). Arumai and co-workers found that the AgNPs with Curcuma longa L. (tumeric) capping exhibited antioxidant and cytotoxicity activity compared to the AgNPs synthesized with Allium sativum L. extract or Camellia sinensis L. extract capping.(25)
    In Figure 4B, no association between the SPR values and the IC50/LD50 was found. In the study of Nakkala and co-workers where AgNPs with capping of Ficus religiosa leaves extract were synthesized, it was observed that AgNPs with a SPR value of 421 nm (21 nm of size) presented the lowest value of IC50/LD50 (1.9 μg/mL) among the various studies in the cancer lung model.(21) The authors observed that besides a moderate antibacterial effect against four bacterial strains (P. fluorescence, S. typhi, B. subtilis, and E. coli), these AgNPs increased ROS formation in A549 cells, which suggests that AgNPs may act as a pro-oxidant in cells. Moreover, the DAPI staining also indicated the occurrence of condensation/fragmentation in these cells, which confirmed the cellular changes associated with apoptosis.(21) In this study, the in vivo experiments revealed an increase in AST, ALT, LDH, TNF-a, and IL-6 serum levels on day 29 following oral administration of Ficus religiosa-based AgNPs, these effects being reverted at the end of the washout period.(21) In contrast, the study performed by Sankar and Palaniappan and co-workers found IC50/LD50 values of 100 μg/mL associated with AgNPs capped with Origanum vulgare aqueous extract and sea grass Cymodocea serrulata aqueous extract, respectively.(52,53) Sankar and co-workers propose that AgNPs have the potential to compete with commercial antimicrobial agents, since the AgNPs used showed inhibition capacity against E. coli, A. hydrophila, Salmonella sps., S. dysenteriae, S. paratyphi, and Sh. Sonnei. Regarding the anticancer activity of the Origanum vulgare aqueous extract-based AgNPs, the authors found a dose–response effect for A549 cells, suggesting that these nanoparticles can induce ROS formation and cause damage in cellular components that can lead to cell death.(52) Palaniappan and co-workers also demonstrated the cytotoxicity potential of AgNPs against the human lung cancer A549 cells at different concentrations, hypothesizing that the cytotoxicity can be a consequence of the permeability of cellular barriers to AgNPs and by the release of ROS that can induce much biological damage.(53)
    Concerning the AgNPs’ size and the IC50/LD50 (Figure 4C), no correlational pattern was observed. For example, it can be observed that the AgNPs with the lowest size (6.13 nm) originated an IC50/LD50 of 11.11 μg/mL.(25) On the other hand, the lowest observed IC50/LD50 (1.9 μg/mL) was obtained when AgNPs with size of 21 nm were incubated with A549 cells.(21) Additionally, in another study with AgNPs capped with Rosa damascena petals aqueous extract that had the same size (21 nm), the IC50 was determined at 80 μg/mL.(54) Furthermore, AgNPs synthesized with sea grass Cymodocea serrulata aqueous extract by Palaniappan and co-workers were associated with an IC50/LD50 of 100 μg/mL, despite the low size of AgNPs (15 nm).(53) He and colleagues synthesized AgNPs with Longan peel powder capping and 15 nm of size; however when used in the A549 cell line, the IC50/LD50 was lower (5.33 μg/mL) than the value found in the Palaniappan and co-workers study.(55) Interestingly, Dadashpour and co-workers synthesized the largest AgNPs with a size of 30.50 nm, but the IC50/LD50 is intermediate (62.82 μg/mL) compared to the other studies in the analysis.(56) The results of these authors showed that high AgNPs concentrations (60 and 100 μg/mL) had a greater effect on cell viability than low concentrations, inducing morphological changes that are associated with typical characteristics of apoptosis and inhibit cell cycle progression.(56) This evidence suggests the possible influence and different biological effects of different types of capping in the AgNPs.
    For the graphical representation of IC50/LD50 vs exposure time, in Figure 4D, only the studies with the A549 cell line were considered, since this was the most frequent cell line used as lung cancer in vitro model to test the influence of the AgNPs. This cell line was established in 1972 by Giard and co-workers through explant culture of lung carcinomatous tissue from a 58-year-old Caucasian male.(57) In general, the studies focused on the evaluation of cell viability and cytotoxicity analysis, apoptosis, ROS formation, and cell cycle analysis. When comparing the IC50/LD50 at the different times of exposure, it can be observed that the analysis at 24 h after incubation is the most frequent time point. Additionally, there is a trend of lower IC50/LD50 after 24 h exposure when compared to 36 and 72 h of exposure. However, this evidence must be interpreted with caution, since there are only two studies evaluating the effects of AgNPs exposure after 36 h and one study evaluating the effects of AgNPs exposure after 72 h. The depicted results reveal the need to carry out tests with longer exposure times.

    5.3. Head and Neck Cancer

    In Figure 5, it can be observed that there is no correlation between the size of AgNPs obtained by TEM with the SPR wavelength (Figure 5A), between the IC50/LD50 and SPR (Figure 5B), and between IC50/LD50 and size (Figure 5C).
    In this tumor model, the lowest SPR of AgNPs (421 nm) was obtained by synthesis with Ficus religiosa leaves extract. This SPR was associated with a low IC50 value (1.6 μg/mL), despite the high size of the AgNPs (21 nm) (Figure 5C).(21) This observation seems to contradict the general idea that bigger AgNPs have less uptake than smaller ones.(19) This may be explained by the importance of the chemical nature of capping and its source, in the functional effect of AgNPs. In fact, in the study of Arumais and co-workers, the authors used extracts of different plant species (different capping) to obtain AgNPs that displayed similar SPR bands and sizes but that were associated with different IC50 values.(25)
    In Figure 5D, considering the high number of papers using the Hep-2 cell line, only the studies using this cell line were used to generate the graphical representations. It is not possible to analyze the correlation between IC50/LD50 values and the 48 h exposure time, since the number of papers available is low. Even so, at the 24 h AgNPs’ exposure time, a significant dispersion of IC50/LD50 values was observed.

    5.4. Gynecological Cancer

    Regarding the gynecologic cancers correlations, despite the different size determination methods used, it can be concluded that there is no correlation between the size (nm) and SPR (nm) between the AgNPs synthesized using different biological natural sources. Even when only TEM, HRTEM, and XRD analyses were considered, the lack of correlation persisted (Figure 6A). This can be due to the different capping biological nature. Moreover, these capping sources contain chemical compounds capable of reducing the ionic silver to its metallic state and stabilize the formed AgNPs. The different reducing potential of those compounds undoubtedly influences the rate of nucleation and growing stages during AgNPs formation and consequently their final shape, sizes, and physicochemical properties. Additionally, the mechanism by which the AgNPs get stabilized by the capping compounds is also different according to the biological source used for the syntheses.
    Regarding the graphical representation of SPR (nm) vs IC50/LD50 (μg/mL), no apparent correlation was observed (Figure 6B). Nevertheless, two separate main groups of data can be identified: one with a SPR band at approximately 420 nm, which showed IC50/LD50 values inferior to 50 μg/mL (group I), and another corresponding to a SPR band at approximately 450 nm, with IC50/LD50 values less than 30 μg/mL (group II). Two scattered points, at IC50 of 150 μg/mL and 200 μg/mL, can be observed corresponding to the capping of wheat straw (lignin) and culture supernatant of Nocardiopsis sp. MBRC-1.(58,59) Considering that the wheat straw has antineoplastic properties, one would expect a very low IC50 value, but this was not observed in this study. The IC50/LD50 values are always dependent on the solution’s preparation method of different concentrations of AgNPs, and hence, some authors apply purification procedures (centrifugation and resuspension, for example) before the AgNPs solutions preparation, and others do not. The execution of this procedure influences the real content of AgNPs in a suspension prepared for a precalculated mass/volume concentration.
    In group I, the IC50/LD50 values range between 1.75 and 59.00 μg/mL. This wide range of IC50/LD50 values might be due to the different biological capping sources used to stabilize the AgNPs and/or for the different core sizes of the nanostructures, mainly between 10 and 50 nm (TEM measurements only). Comparing the works of Nakkala et al. and Venkatesan et al.,(21,60) the average AgNPs size was similar (21.00 and 22.50 nm), while the IC50 values were 1.75 and 59 μg/mL, respectively. This may show the higher predominance of the capping source influence in the cytotoxicity of AgNPs and must be thoroughly investigated in the future. Alternatively, similar IC50 values (35.00 and 34.50 μg/mL) were obtained in the works of Venkatesan and Chanthini and co-workers,(61,62) but they used AgNPs of different capping and sizes (50.00 and 23.00 nm, respectively). Regarding group II, there is a possible association between SPR (nm) and IC50/LD50 (μg/mL), where increasing SPR values correlate to increasing IC50/LD50 values. Nevertheless, the number of works remains small to allow more consistent conclusions.
    In Figure 6C, there is no correlation between size (nm) vs IC50/LD50 (μg/mL). The diversity of techniques for measuring the AgNPs size becomes inconsistent for any possible correlation between size and SPR peaks of the AgNPs. Furthermore, it is difficult to conclude about the relation of size and the effective entrance of the AgNPs inside the cells, which in turn influence their cytotoxic capacity (IC50/LD50).
    Yet, in these works all the TEM and XRD size measurements are quite similar in range (6.13 and 14.00 nm) as well the IC50 values (13.74–17.86 μg/mL) with one exception. The work of Aziz et al.(45) used silver nanoparticles of size 10.50 nm, and the obtained IC50 value on HeLa cancer cells was very low, namely, 1.87 μg/mL. In this work, the biological effect of the compounds contained in the Piriformospora indica extract might have strong interactions with the cancer cell metabolism, membrane, DNA, etc., causing their necrosis or apoptosis. Additionally, according to the authors, the main advantage of these nanoparticles is their protein-based capping which made their entry easier into the cells. Thus, the obtained IC50 value in this work may be the result of the AgNPs cytotoxicity with the biological effects of the compounds contained in the Piriformospora indica extract.
    Figure 6D compares the IC50/LD50 values for the HeLa cell line at different exposure times, namely, 24, 48, and 120 h, indicating relatively low differences between the average IC50/LD50 values. Nevertheless, the gathered data only allowed identification of 9 results of IC50/LD50 analysis for 24 h, 3 for 48 h and 1 to 120 h, and thus, some cautions with conclusions must be present. Still, it is important to notice that for this cell line, the IC50/LD50 values are already low at 24 h exposure time.

    5.5. Urologic Cancer

    In Figure 7A, a trend between the size and SPR can be observed: the higher is the SPR, the higher is the measured size of the AgNPs. However, it is important to mention that the sizes were obtained by SEM or TEM, which introduces some interpretation bias on the depicted correlation.
    Regarding Figure 7B, the relation between SPR and IC50/LD50 is heterogeneous. For example, for similar IC50/LD50 values there are different SPR values, as it is observed in the works of He and collaborators, who used Cornus officinalis as capping agents, and Prasannaraj and collaborators, who used Terminalia arjuna barks extracts.(28,63) In these examples, the AgNPs presented SPR at 411 and 450 nm, and the IC50/LD50 values were 25.54 and 28.42 μg/mL, respectively.
    Regarding size and IC50/LD50 graphical representation, a dispersion of the values is observed (Figure 7C). In fact, He and Bello and co-workers synthesized AgNPs with the same range of IC50/LD50 (25.54 μg/mL and 23.48 μg/mL, respectively) but different AgNPs sizes (11.70 and 50 nm, respectively).(63,64) On the other hand, in two independent studies performed by He and co-workers, AgNPs with 12 nm of size were associated with IC50/LD50 of 25.54 μg/mL and 87.33 μg/mL.(55,63)
    In Figure 7D, only papers using the PC-3 cell line and the exposure time of 48 h were considered, due to the lack of information available regarding other exposure times. The data represented show a high dispersion of IC50/LD50 values (between 6.85 μg/mL and 58.61 μg/mL).

    5.6. Digestive Cancer

    Regarding the AgNPs related cytotoxicity works in digestive cancer cell lines, the correlation size (nm) vs SPR (nm) represented in Figure 8A only comprises the studies where the AgNPs were analyzed by TEM or HR-TEM. The plotted results show a subtle tendency for higher sizes of AgNPs as the SPR peak shifts to higher wavelengths, which is in accordance with the literature.(65)
    The graphical representation of crossing values between SPR and IC50/LD50 (Figure 8B) does not reveal any correlation. Nevertheless, one can observe an accumulation of values less than 6 μg/mL for IC50/LD50 scattered between 410 and 450 nm (SPR), approximately, which all correspond to results obtained upon 24 h exposure time of AgNPs to digestive cancer cell lines. On the other hand, the highest IC50/LD50 value (175 μg/mL) obtained after 48 h of exposure time corresponds to a high SPR value (440 nm).
    The variation of AgNPs size vs the corresponding IC50/LD50 values was analyzed and was only represented for the papers in which the AgNPs size was determined by TEM (Figure 8C). The lack of association between the size and IC50/LD50 values may be attributed to the diversity of the biological sources used for the reduction and capping of the synthesized AgNPs. Additionally, the different purification treatments to which the AgNPs suspensions are subjected (or not) after the synthesis procedure add another uncontrollable variable: if the AgNPs’ suspensions used for the cytotoxicity tests contain remains of bioactive and therapeutic compounds and in unknown concentrations, the IC50/LD50 values determined by the researchers will be due to the dual effect of the biocapped AgNPs and the chemically bioactive compounds of the natural sources extracts present in the suspension medium. For example, considering the works of Mata and Nakkala and co-workers, both used AgNPs with 15 and 21 nm (TEM analysis), respectively, with an exposure time of 24 h with the colorectal adenocarcinoma cell line (COLO205), and both distinct biocapped AgNPs originated an IC50 value equivalent to 4 μg/mL.(21,66) Nevertheless, Nakkala and collaborators in their work treated the synthesized AgNPs suspension by centrifugation at 18 000 rpm for 25 min and repeated washing with double distilled water to eliminate any unbound bioactive compounds that could interfere with the AgNPs assays. The work of Mata and co-workers does not mention any suspension treatment for purification, so part of the cytotoxicity effect could be due to the remaining biobased compounds from the synthesis procedure present in the suspension medium and acting in parallel with AgNPs normal cytotoxicity mechanisms, as if it were a synergistic effect.
    In Figure 8D, the scarce number of studies at 24 h exposure time and the high dispersion of values at 48 h limit the conclusions regarding the influence of the natural products-based AgNPs exposure time in the IC50/LD50 of the cancer cell line HepG2. In fact, similar averages of IC50/LD50 results can be observed for both exposure times.

    5.7. Skin Cancer

    In Figure 9A, a high dispersion of the AgNPs’ size values according to SPR was observed. Yet, this dispersion of values is directly related to the fact that due to the scarce availability of works to analyze related to skin cancer, the graphical representation in Figure 9A involves all the collected works from literature, implying that the sizes of AgNPs depicted in the figure were obtained by several techniques: FE-TEM, SEM, XRD, DLS, and TEM. As already mentioned, these techniques evaluate dimensions of different structures, like the nanoparticles core only or the average crystallite particle size (by using the Debye–Scherrer formula) or the hydrodynamic size of the nanoparticles.
    However, a correlation between low SPR and high IC50 values was observed in Figure 9B. Furthermore, in Figure 9C, similar IC50/LD50 values were obtained when using AgNPs of different sizes. Nevertheless, it is important to highlight that these sizes were obtained by diverse instrumental techniques (SEM, TEM, XRD, and DLS) which can explain some of these observations, as already mentioned above.
    Regarding AgNPs cytotoxicity assays in skin cancer cell lines, two independent studies need to be highlighted, conducted by Nayak and collaborators(29,67) aiming at testing the influence of the natural product origin of capping in the AgNPs cytotoxicity. In the first, petals of C. maxima (which is an antibacterial, antitumor, antidiabetic, antihypertensive, immunomodulatory, and anti-inflammatory agent), leaves of M. oleifera (which is a source of vitamins A, B and C, essential amino acids, omega 3 and 6 fatty acids), and rhizome of A. calamus (which shows medicinal properties against cough, fever, asthma, bronchitis, digestive problems, nerve tonic, and expectorant) were used to synthesize three different AgNPs.(67) These AgNPs presented the same SPR and overlapped IC50 at 48 h exposure time, showing no influence of the capping in AgNPs’ properties (82.39, 83.57, 78.58 μg/mL). In the second study, the AgNPs with Eclipta prostate and Alternanthera sessilis plant extracts capping(29) had very close dimensions and the IC50 values obtained in the cytotoxic assays showed no apparent difference (70.59 μg/mL and 70.52 μg/mL). These plants were selected, according to the authors, due to their use in treatment of hair loss, body pain, vision diminishing, indigestion, jaundice, liver diseases, spleen, skin diseases, memory impairment, atherosclerosis, hepatic disorders, anti-snake venoms (Eclipta prostate) and antipyretic, hepatoprotective, antiulcer, antibacterial, hematinic, and diuretic activities (Alternanthera sessilis).
    Figure 9D, which only considered the papers using Hep2 cell line, shows superior IC50/LD50 values after 48 h of exposure when compared with 24 h. Nevertheless, it is important to take into consideration the low number of studies used in this graphical representation.

    5.8. Other Cancers

    In Figure 10, the information regarding the use of AgNPs, synthesized using natural products, in glioblastoma, neuroblastoma, retinoblastoma, and myeloblastic leukemia cell lines is presented.
    Concerning the correlation between AgNPs’ size and SPR (Figure 10A), a high heterogeneity of crossed values was observed. In the study performed by Patra and co-workers, which used Butea monosperma leaf extract, the high value of SPR (450 nm) was associated with AgNPs with the highest core size (50 nm) among the different studies,(49) as expected. However, some discrepancies were observed in other studies. For example, in the work conducted by Govindaraju and co-workers, which used AgNPs synthesized with Sargassum vulgare extract capping,(68) a relatively low SPR value of 419 nm was associated with AgNPs of 10 nm size, while, on the other hand, Safaepour and co-workers synthesized AgNPs based in geraniol (primary component of rose oil, palmarosa oil, and citronella oil) and NaOH, with a SPR of 440 nm but with 6 nm of size.(69)
    In Figure 10B, a correlation between IC50/LD50 and SPR can be observed. Among all the works included in the section “Other” cancer models of Table 1, the study of Safaepour and co-workers,(69) determined the lowest IC50/LD50 (2.60 μg/mL), tested in a mouse fibrosarcoma cell line, when using AgNPs capped with geraniol/NaOH with a SPR at 440 nm. On the opposite side, the AgNPs synthesized using marine seaweed Turbinaria ornata, by Remya and co-workers, with a SPR of 428 nm were associated with high IC50/ID50 values observed in the analyzed studies (10.50 μg/mL).(70)
    In Figure 10C, the correlation between IC50/LD50 and size can be observed. As expected, we observed that administration of larger sized AgNPs (18 nm) to the retinoblastoma Y79 cell line was associated with the highest IC50/LD50 observed among the studies reviewed,(70) that is, when using marine seaweed Turbinaria ornata for the synthesis. In fact, the administration of AgNPs with marine seaweed Turbinaria ornata capping showed that the cell viability decreases with the use of increasing AgNPs concentration. The authors suggested that the cytotoxic effect could be due to its size and capping as a consequence of the active physical and chemical interactions of silver ions with the functional groups of intracellular proteins.(70)
    The lowest IC50/LD50 (2.84 μg/mL and 2.6 μg/mL) values were obtained with the use of AgNPs synthesized with Sargassum vulgare extract capping and geraniol/NaOH, in human leukemia cell lines and mouse fibrosarcoma, respectively.(68,69) Govindaraju and co-workers suggested that the AgNPs induce cell death through apoptosis, starting the process by DNA fragmentation.(68) Furthermore, Safaepour and co-workers also observed a dose–response effect between the cytotoxicity and the increase of concentration.(69) The highest IC50/LD50 value of 10.50 μg/mL was observed in the study of Remya and co-workers when using AgNPs based on marine seaweed Turbinaria ornata, with nanoparticles dimensions of 18 nm.(70) In this study, the cytotoxic effect of the AgNPs was dose dependent and the tumoral cells displayed distinct morphological changes after treatment.(70)

    6. Conclusions and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    AgNPs have shown great potential in numerous applications, namely, in the biomedical field. However, when synthesized by chemical methods, they are highly pollutant and show great signs of toxicity in healthy cells. The green approach to AgNPs synthesis seems to have brought solutions to these problems since it uses nonpollutant reagents and the AgNPs produced are more compatible with healthy cells.
    Green synthesis of AgNPs mostly relies in the usage of plants, algae, or microorganisms extracts as capping, that is, natural products. In fact, most of the studies reviewed used plant extracts as capping agents for the AgNPs. The majors advantages of using plant derivates or respective extracts for this synthesis are the avoidance of unwanted pathogenicity (that may occur when using microbial derived synthesis) and the faster reduction rates of silver ions in comparison with microorganisms-mediated synthesis.(17)
    Regarding the natural-products-based AgNPs’ anticancer properties, they consistently show great potential in killing cancer cells, even the most resistant ones, being a potential new therapeutic approach. Additionally, since AgNPs produce different types of damages and they can damage different organelles of the cells, they may have the capacity to restore the sensitivity of current therapies. Thus, their ability to increase the production of ROS in cancer cells may revert their resistance to radiotherapy, since this therapy triggers the production of ROS and, like that, induces tumor cells death. On the other side, because of the damage they induce in the DNA and in the cellular membrane as well as their ability to interfere with the cell cycle, they may help restore the chemotherapy sensitivity, since this therapy’s effect is achieved through damages in the DNA and in the inhibition of mitosis. Furthermore, the fact that AgNPs affect several molecular pathways can improve targeted therapies efficiency. One example is the capacity of AgNPs to downregulate the proangiogenic factor VEGF. Angiogenesis is associated with cancer progression, and it is currently one of the pathways with more targeted therapies available, but these therapies present limited effects regarding disease control. Thus, the emerging of AgNPs based on natural products as potential angiogenesis inhibitors seems very promising. Even though scarce, there are already some studies pointing to the efficiency of AgNPs synthesized by green methods in vivo. He and co-workers have shown that an intraperitoneal injection of AgNPs with longan peel capping was able to prevent tumor growth of non-small-cell lung cancer in severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice.(55) Additionally, some authors have also studied the in vivo effects of AgNPs in healthy mice, concluding that the body weight, serum markers, and oxidative stress markers in liver of this mice returned to normal after the washout period, showing the biocompatibility of these AgNPs.(21)
    Moreover, one of the main problems regarding cancer therapy is the toxicity and consequent comorbidities that they bring to cancer patients. A synergistic approach combining AgNPs with current therapies can bring several benefits. In fact, some studies have also shown AgNPs’ ability to enhance current anticancer therapies, either by being added to cancer cells in concomitance with the other drugs or by being an efficient drug carrier. Thus, by combination of two therapies, the doses of both AgNPs and the other medicine can be lower, and because AgNPs’ toxicity regarding normal cells is significantly lower, this would mean that there would be less side toxicity to cancer patients.
    Despite being extensively studied, there are several current limitations in the existing studies that restrict the conclusions. First, the effect of AgNPs must be interpreted in the context of a specific cell line because it was observed a significant heterogeneity of effects according to the type of cell line. Moreover, because of this specificity, the comparison between tumor and normal cell lines must be done concerning the type of cells to better support the conclusions. Thus, more studies regarding the toxicity of AgNPs in healthy cells as well as their damage in metabolizing and excreting organs shall be done to evaluate the safety of this potential therapeutic approach.
    The heterogeneity observed in this review reveals the importance of uniformization among studies. The IC50/LD50 calculation method may influence the results of the study since it may be related only to atomic silver, to the mass of AgNPs, or to the concentration of AgNPs. If for IC50/LD50 the parameter unit is mass/volume, then it must be ensured that the weighed mass is only of AgNPs with the respective capping. If this is not the case, then the IC50/LD50 values might reflect the effect of the AgNPs, its capping, and/or the bioactive natural products extract remains that also have cytotoxic effects, which will influence the results. Additionally, the purification method of AgNPs will also influence its effect. Thus, the works involving the use of AgNPs in biological assays should state if some separation or purification procedure was performed over the AgNPs, discarding the possibility for occurrence of simultaneous lateral effects of chemical compounds (syntheses wastes) in the cellular assays. The authors also should always include a thorough description of the procedure used in the cytotoxicity assays so that a better comparison could be conducted between different research works.
    AgNPs synthesized with natural products represent a green alternative with great potential to future cancer therapies. In this review, their effect has been shown to depend not only on the chosen capping but also on the tumor model in which they are applied. Nevertheless, the cytotoxic effect of AgNPs based on natural products in cancer cells and its biocompatibility with normal cells is consistent. Currently, there is no standard method for AgNPs synthesis and, most importantly, characterization, which limits the comparison between the analyzed studies and limits the conclusions regarding the best size, capping, quantities, and exposure time for each tumor model. A good standardization of AgNPs’ characterization would, thus, be of benefit to establish the parameters that maximize the anticancer effect for each tumor model.
    The application of green-based AgNPs in oncology research is still an open and promising field, and there is a need of additional studies regarding the optimal production and characterization of AgNPs as well as of their effects in cancer cells.

    The authors declare no competing financial interest.

    1. 1
      Bray, F.; Ferlay, J.; Soerjomataram, I.; Siegel, R. L.; Torre, L. A.; Jemal, A. Global Cancer Statistics 2018: Globocan Estimates of Incidence and Mortality Worldwide for 36 Cancers in 185 Countries. Ca-Cancer J. Clin. 2018, 68, 394– 424,  DOI: 10.3322/caac.21492
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Global cancer statistics 2018: GLOBOCAN estimates of incidence and mortality worldwide for 36 cancers in 185 countries
      Bray Freddie; Ferlay Jacques; Soerjomataram Isabelle; Siegel Rebecca L; Torre Lindsey A; Jemal Ahmedin
      CA: a cancer journal for clinicians (2018), 68 (6), 394-424 ISSN:.
      This article provides a status report on the global burden of cancer worldwide using the GLOBOCAN 2018 estimates of cancer incidence and mortality produced by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, with a focus on geographic variability across 20 world regions. There will be an estimated 18.1 million new cancer cases (17.0 million excluding nonmelanoma skin cancer) and 9.6 million cancer deaths (9.5 million excluding nonmelanoma skin cancer) in 2018. In both sexes combined, lung cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer (11.6% of the total cases) and the leading cause of cancer death (18.4% of the total cancer deaths), closely followed by female breast cancer (11.6%), prostate cancer (7.1%), and colorectal cancer (6.1%) for incidence and colorectal cancer (9.2%), stomach cancer (8.2%), and liver cancer (8.2%) for mortality. Lung cancer is the most frequent cancer and the leading cause of cancer death among males, followed by prostate and colorectal cancer (for incidence) and liver and stomach cancer (for mortality). Among females, breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer and the leading cause of cancer death, followed by colorectal and lung cancer (for incidence), and vice versa (for mortality); cervical cancer ranks fourth for both incidence and mortality. The most frequently diagnosed cancer and the leading cause of cancer death, however, substantially vary across countries and within each country depending on the degree of economic development and associated social and life style factors. It is noteworthy that high-quality cancer registry data, the basis for planning and implementing evidence-based cancer control programs, are not available in most low- and middle-income countries. The Global Initiative for Cancer Registry Development is an international partnership that supports better estimation, as well as the collection and use of local data, to prioritize and evaluate national cancer control efforts. CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians 2018;0:1-31. © 2018 American Cancer Society.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Noninvasive Imaging of Nanomedicines and Nanotheranostics: Principles, Progress, and Prospects
      Kunjachan, Sijumon; Ehling, Josef; Storm, Gert; Kiessling, Fabian; Lammers, Twan
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 115 (19), 10907-10937CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on the most important applications of noninvasive imaging techniques such as PET, SPECT, CT, MRI, OI and US in the use of nanomedicines and nanotheranostics (e.g., liposomes, polymers, micelles, dendrimers, nanoparticles, antibodies) for facilitating disease diagnosis, disease treatment, and treatment monitoring, including drug delivery research.

    4. 4
      Zugazagoitia, J.; Guedes, C.; Ponce, S.; Ferrer, I.; Molina-Pinelo, S.; Paz-Ares, L. Current Challenges in Cancer Treatment. Clin. Ther. 2016, 38, 1551– 1566,  DOI: 10.1016/j.clinthera.2016.03.026
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Current Challenges in Cancer Treatment
      Zugazagoitia Jon; Ponce Santiago; Guedes Cristiano; Ferrer Irene; Molina-Pinelo Sonia; Paz-Ares Luis
      Clinical therapeutics (2016), 38 (7), 1551-66 ISSN:.
      PURPOSE: In this review, we highlight the current concepts and discuss some of the current challenges and future prospects in cancer therapy. We frequently use the example of lung cancer. METHODS: We conducted a nonsystematic PubMed search, selecting the most comprehensive and relevant research articles, clinical trials, translational papers, and review articles on precision oncology and immuno-oncology. Papers were prioritized and selected based on their originality and potential clinical applicability. FINDINGS: Two major revolutions have changed cancer treatment paradigms in the past few years: targeting actionable alterations in oncogene-driven cancers and immuno-oncology. Important challenges are still ongoing in both fields of cancer therapy. On the one hand, druggable genomic alterations are diverse and represent only small subsets of patients in certain tumor types, which limits testing their clinical impact in biomarker-driven clinical trials. Next-generation sequencing technologies are increasingly being implemented for molecular prescreening in clinical research, but issues regarding clinical interpretation of large genomic data make their wide clinical use difficult. Further, dealing with tumor heterogeneity and acquired resistance is probably the main limitation for the success of precision oncology. On the other hand, long-term survival benefits with immune checkpoint inhibitors (anti-programmed death cell protein-1/programmed death cell ligand-1[PD-1/L1] and anti-cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 monoclonal antibodies) are restricted to a minority of patients, and no predictive markers are yet robustly validated that could help us recognize these subsets and optimize treatment delivery and selection. To achieve long-term survival benefits, drug combinations targeting several molecular alterations or cancer hallmarks might be needed. This will probably be one of the most challenging but promising precision cancer treatment strategies in the future. IMPLICATIONS: Targeting single molecular abnormalities or cancer pathways has achieved good clinical responses that have modestly affected survival in some cancers. However, this approach to cancer treatment is still reductionist, and many challenges need to be met to improve treatment outcomes with our patients.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC28bnsVCisg%253D%253D&md5=8b4909be37191a1a9c790eae0e96d154
    5. 5
      Mansoori, B.; Mohammadi, A.; Davudian, S.; Shirjang, S.; Baradaran, B. The Different Mechanisms of Cancer Drug Resistance: A Brief Review. Adv. Pharm. Bull. 2017, 7, 339– 348,  DOI: 10.15171/apb.2017.041
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The different mechanisms of cancer drug resistance: a brief review
      Mansoori, Behzad; Mohammadi, Ali; Davudian, Sadaf; Shirjang, Solmaz; Baradaran, Behzad
      Advanced Pharmaceutical Bulletin (2017), 7 (3), 339-348CODEN: APBDCL; ISSN:2251-7308. (Tabriz University of Medical Sciences)
      Anticancer drugs resistance is a complex process that arises from altering in the drug targets. Advances in the DNA microarray, proteomics technol. and the development of targeted therapies provide the new strategies to overcome the drug resistance. Although a design of the new chemotherapy agents is growing quickly, effective chemotherapy agent has not been discovered against the advanced stage of cancer (such as invasion and metastasis). The cancer cell resistance against the anticancer agents can be due to many factors such as the individual's genetic differences, esp. in tumoral somatic cells. Also, the cancer drug resistance is acquired, the drug resistance can be occurred by different mechanisms, including multi-drug resistance, cell death inhibiting (apoptosis suppression), altering in the drug metab., epigenetic and drug targets, enhancing DNA repair and gene amplification. In this review, we outlined the mechanisms of cancer drug resistance and in following, the treatment failures by common chemotherapy agents in the different type of cancers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXktFCntbk%253D&md5=889d5efbe4bca0f1c3946f55848a13ee
    6. 6
      Graham, K.; Unger, E. Overcoming Tumor Hypoxia as a Barrier to Radiotherapy, Chemotherapy and Immunotherapy in Cancer Treatment. Int. J. Nanomed. 2018, 13, 6049– 6058,  DOI: 10.2147/IJN.S140462
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Overcoming tumor hypoxia as a barrier to radiotherapy, chemotherapy and immunotherapy in cancer treatment
      Graham, Kaitlin; Unger, Evan
      International Journal of Nanomedicine (2018), 13 (), 6049-6058CODEN: IJNNHQ; ISSN:1178-2013. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
      A review. The levels of oxygenation within the same tumor are highly variable from one area to another and can change over time. Tumor hypoxia is an important impediment to effective cancer therapy. In radiotherapy, the primary mechanism is the creation of reactive oxygen species; hypoxic tumors are therefore radiation resistant. A no. of chemotherapeutic drugs have been shown to be less effective when exposed to a hypoxic environment which can lead to further disease progression. Hypoxia is also a potent barrier to effective immunotherapy in cancer treatment. Because of the recognition of hypoxia as an important barrier to cancer treatment, a variety of approaches have been undertaken to overcome or reverse tumor hypoxia. Such approaches have included breathing hyperbaric oxygen, artificial Hbs, allosteric Hb modifiers, hypoxia activated prodrugs and fluorocarbons (FCs). These approaches have largely failed due to limited efficacy and/or adverse side effects. Oxygen therapeutics, based on liq. FCs, can potentially increase the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood to reverse tumor hypoxia. Currently, at least two drugs are in clin. trials to reverse tumor hypoxia; one of these is designed to improve permeability of oxygen into the tumor tissue and the other is based upon a low b.p. FC that transports higher amts. of oxygen per g than previously tested FCs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtVenu7jL&md5=954b3c615b7cf6ce37baaba79ebb25d2
    7. 7
      Hsieh, J. J.; Purdue, M. P.; Signoretti, S.; Swanton, C.; Albiges, L.; Schmidinger, M.; Heng, D. Y.; Larkin, J.; Ficarra, V. Renal Cell Carcinoma. Nat. Rev. Dis. Primers 2017, 3, 17009,  DOI: 10.1038/nrdp.2017.9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Renal cell carcinoma
      Hsieh James J; Purdue Mark P; Signoretti Sabina; Swanton Charles; Albiges Laurence; Schmidinger Manuela; Heng Daniel Y; Larkin James; Ficarra Vincenzo
      Nature reviews. Disease primers (2017), 3 (), 17009 ISSN:.
      Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) denotes cancer originated from the renal epithelium and accounts for >90% of cancers in the kidney. The disease encompasses >10 histological and molecular subtypes, of which clear cell RCC (ccRCC) is most common and accounts for most cancer-related deaths. Although somatic VHL mutations have been described for some time, more-recent cancer genomic studies have identified mutations in epigenetic regulatory genes and demonstrated marked intra-tumour heterogeneity, which could have prognostic, predictive and therapeutic relevance. Localized RCC can be successfully managed with surgery, whereas metastatic RCC is refractory to conventional chemotherapy. However, over the past decade, marked advances in the treatment of metastatic RCC have been made, with targeted agents including sorafenib, sunitinib, bevacizumab, pazopanib and axitinib, which inhibit vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and its receptor (VEGFR), and everolimus and temsirolimus, which inhibit mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1), being approved. Since 2015, agents with additional targets aside from VEGFR have been approved, such as cabozantinib and lenvatinib; immunotherapies, such as nivolumab, have also been added to the armamentarium for metastatic RCC. Here, we provide an overview of the biology of RCC, with a focus on ccRCC, as well as updates to complement the current clinical guidelines and an outline of potential future directions for RCC research and therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1czksV2rsA%253D%253D&md5=2a5549361f8617341ae0c927bb47e9f4
    8. 8
      Maughan, B. L.; Antonarakis, E. S. Androgen Pathway Resistance in Prostate Cancer and Therapeutic Implications. Expert Opin. Pharmacother. 2015, 16, 1521– 1537,  DOI: 10.1517/14656566.2015.1055249
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Androgen pathway resistance in prostate cancer and therapeutic implications
      Maughan, Benjamin L.; Antonarakis, Emmanuel S.
      Expert Opinion on Pharmacotherapy (2015), 16 (10), 1521-1537CODEN: EOPHF7; ISSN:1465-6566. (Informa Healthcare)
      Introduction: Metastatic prostate cancer is an incurable disease that is treated with a variety of hormonal therapies targeting various nodes of the androgen receptor (AR) pathway. Invariably patients develop resistance and become castration resistant. Common treatments for castration-resistant disease include novel hormonal therapies, such as abiraterone and enzalutamide, chemotherapy, immunotherapy and radiopharmaceuticals. As this disease generally remains incurable, understanding the mol. underpinnings of resistance pathways is crit. in designing therapeutic strategies to delay or overcome such resistance. Areas covered: This review will explore the resistance mechanisms relevant to hormonal agents, such as AR-V7 expression and others, as well as discussing new approaches being developed to treat patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer that take advantage of these new insights. A literature search was performed to identify all published clin. trials related to androgen therapy mechanisms of drug resistance in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. Expert opinion: Androgen therapy resistance mechanisms are varied, and include modification of all nodes in the androgen signaling pathway. The optimal treatment for men with relapsed metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer is uncertain at this time. The authors recommend using available clin. data to guide treatment decision making until more specific biomarkers are clin. available.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFSmsrbJ&md5=2e1d4110fec3e3a63b37aa8906cbaa9c
    9. 9
      Facchinetti, F.; Proto, C.; Minari, R.; Garassino, M.; Tiseo, M. Mechanisms of Resistance to Target Therapies in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer. Handb. Exp. Pharmacol. 2017, 249, 63– 89,  DOI: 10.1007/164_2017_16
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
